Welcome to Serbia!

Sitting in the heart of the Balkans, The Republic of Serbia has a rich history and culture that is best discovered by visiting this fascinating country.

Belgrade (which translates to "white city" in Serbian) is the capital, as well as the largest, city of Serbia, with a population of around 1.2 million people.

Belgrade has been a battleground city for a large part of its history. Occupied by the Byzantine Empire during the Middle Ages, it served as a battleground between different kingdoms and empires for many centuries.\n\nBy the late 14th century, the Ottoman Empire began conquering Serbia, eventually making its way to and seizing Belgrade in 1521. Most of the city was demolished, and its Serbian population, which was predominantly Orthodox Christian, were deported to Istanbul.

In the early 19th century, Serbian revolutionaries began an uprising, eventually reaching semi-independence in 1830. For the rest of the 19th century, Belgrade started changing as it became influenced less by the Ottoman Empire, and more by Central and Western European architecture, as well as romanticist and gothic architecture.

In the 20th century, Belgrade suffered greatly at the hands of the two World Wars, leaving it with more than 10,000 destroyed buildings and houses. Construction works to rebuild Belgrade began after World War 2 but were heavily influenced by the socialist Yugoslavia of which Serbia was a part.

As a result, Belgrade's architecture is wildly varied and walking its streets will provide an interesting and insightful look into its tumultuous history.

We hope you enjoy your visit to Belgrade!

The first place that most people visit is the main pedestrian street, Knez Mihailova, and the nearby Kalemegdan Park. The park houses a very important Serbian monument, the Belgrade Fortress, and it is a popular meet and hang out spot for tourists and locals alike. Stroll down Knez Mihailova for some light shopping and sit in one of the numerous cafes which are full in both winter and summer, and then go for a walk and learn some history in the beautiful Kalemegdan Park.

Local's tip: Visit at sunset for incredible views over the meeting point of the Sava and Danube rivers.

Kalemegdan bb 11000, Belgrade.

The Church of Saint Sava is the largest Orthodox church in Serbia, and one of the largest in the world. It can be seen from all over the city, but its size and grandness cannot be fully appreciated until you are standing right in front of it.

Local's tip: Once you are inside, head downstairs to the crypt. It is free to visit and absolutely beautiful.

The Church of Saint Sava, Krušedolska 2a, Vračar, Belgrade.

While you're in Belgrade, you will undoubtedly walk through many quirky and interesting areas of the city - walking is the best way to discover a city after all! However, one of the lesser visited, but more beautiful areas, is Zemun. Located on the West side of the Sava river, Zemun is known for its many squares and old, cobblestone streets.

Local's tip: Take a leisurely afternoon stroll and visit the Gardos Tower at night.

Gardos Tower, Grobljanska 9, Belgrade.

Serbian food will leave an impression on all visitors. From bakeries selling all kinds of delicious pastries, to fast-food kiosks will a variety of meat cooked in different ways, to ethnic restaurants specialising in Serbian cuisine, you won\'t struggle to find your new favourite meal.\n\nHere are our favourites.

Milosev Konak:

This is a typically Serbian restaurant, serving all the nation's favourites. It's located in the middle of the beautiful Topcider Park, so you can stop by for a hearty meal after a stroll through the park.

Milosev Konak, Topciderska, Belgrade.

Trpkovic Bakery:

A favourite amongst locals, it's not uncommon to see lines winding down the street outside this bakery, especially in the morning while the burek (a cheese pastry) is still hot. Local's tip: try as much as you can.

Trpkovic Bakery, Nemanjina 32, Belgrade.

Zavicaj:

Located in the heart of the trendy Savamala district, this restaurant serves authentic Serbian home-made food in a traditional setting - the kind you would get at your grandma's place.

Zavicaj, Gavrila Principa 77, Belgrade.

Ferdinand Knedle:

After you have eaten Serbian meat to your heart's content, it's time for dessert. A favourite among young locals is dumplings - but not in the way you know them. Savoury or sweet, they are filled with a variety of flavours and rolled in crumbed nuts and chocolate. Order two!

Ferdinand Knedle, Cara Lazara 19, Belgrade.

A trip to Belgrade wouldn\'t be complete without a taste of what it has to offer at nighttime. Serbian people like to go out late and stay out late - and this is made possible by the hundreds of cafe-turn-bars and nightclubs that stay open until their last patrons leave. Start at a \"kafic\", a Serbian cafe by day and bar by night, before making your way to a \"splav\", a floating club.\n\nLocated all along the Sava river, splavs are truly unique to Serbia and provide a night out like you haven\'t ever experienced. Book in advance to reserve a table and avoid getting turned away at the door.
